No. 79 Yingze West Street Taiyuan 030024 China A series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were fabricated by finely adjusting the amount of platinum and investigated in the selective oxidative of ethylene glycol (EG) to glycolic acid (GA) under mild neutral conditions. The 0.90Pt/Al2O3 catalyst showed the maximum turnover frequency (TOF: 1106.6 h−1) with the EG conversion of 74.2 % and GA selectivity of 90.2 %. A strong linear relationship between TOF values and Pt0concentration was revealed, confirming that Pt0 species serves as the active sites for GA formation. In addition, in situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) results verify the reaction pathways of EG oxidation as follows: C2H6O2 → HOCH2CHO → HOCH2COOH. This work unraveled structure-performance relationship for the selective EG oxidation over Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, providing important guidance for the design of efficient noble catalysts especially for the oxidation reaction of polyols. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethylene glycol (EG) Selective oxidation Pt catalysts Structure-performance relationship Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene glycol (EG), as the simplest diol, is widely used in antifreeze, liquid detergents, biodegradable polyester fibers, etc. [1–7]. Nowadays, the global EG production is facing the problem of overcapacity due to the continuous development of biomass conversion and coal chemical industry [8,9]. Hence, it is of great significance for the development of the downstream products with high added value from EG [10,11]. Wherein, glycolic acid (GA) has particularly received a great deal of attention with the versatile applications in disinfectants, industrial cleaning and biodegradable materials [12–14]. As compared with traditional synthetic routes including hydrogen carbonylation of formaldehyde [15,16], alkaline hydrolysis of chloroacetic acid [17,18], the cyanidation hydrolysis [19] and oxalic acid electroreduction [20], the selective oxidation of EG to GA has been considered as one of the greenest and efficient processes [21]. In earlier studies, GA was produced by aqueous-phase oxidation of EG over Au [22,23], Pd [23], Pt [24,25] and Ni(Cu) [26] catalysts in an alkaline solution (NaOH or KOH). The presence of OH– can promote the activation of O–H and C–H bonds in EG molecules through proton transfer and further react with deprotonated EG species (HOCH2CO*) to form GA. Whereas, the alkaline medium leads to the formation of glycolate salts instead of GA, which causes difficulties in the subsequent separation procedure. Therefore, more recently, a great number of studies have been focused on the selective oxidation of EG in a base-free medium [27,28]. In comparison to Au and Pd, Pt is more active for the oxidation of alcohols due to the moderate adsorption strength with alcohol molecules and what's more it is more tolerant to reaction medium conditions [29–32]. The electronic structure of Pt species is closely related to the performance of the Pt-based catalysts and the regulation of electronic structures by adjusting the carrier properties and constructing bimetallic active sites has been identified as efficient strategy in enhancing the catalytic performance [27,28,33–35]. For example, Du et al. [27] recently reported that the electron coupling effect occurring on the Pt/NaY catalyst could form electron-rich Pt sites, which was more conducive to the EG oxidation reaction. Yan et al. [28] also found the strong electronic coupling effect on the PtMn/MCM-41 catalyst, in which the electron transfers from Mn to Pt at the Pt-Mn2O3 interface resulted in enhancement catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of EG to GA. In addition, Pt is often supported on alumina and employed in the catalytic oxidation reactions, and the strong interaction between Pt atoms and the unsaturated AlV Lewis acids can be used to effectively regulate the Pt sizes to achieve perfect catalytic performance [36,37]. For instance, Kwak's group found that the strong Pt-Al2O3 interaction affected the morphology and size of Pt clusters, which resulted in highly dispersed 2D PtO2 rafts (1 nm) and atomically dispersed Pt atoms at low Pt loading (1 wt% Pt/Al2O3). While, it was dominated by 3D PtO2 particles (>2 nm) and large Pt crystals (>10 nm) in the 1 wt% Pt/SiO2 catalyst with a weak metal-support interaction. In the present work, a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with the Pt loading from 0.80 to 1.00 wt% were prepared by the impregnation method and tested in the selective oxidation of EG in a base-free medium. Various characterizations were conducted to explore to the effect of Pt loading on catalyst structure. The relationship between TOF values and Pt0 concentration was explored. In addition, the reaction mechanisms of the selective oxidation of EG were confirmed by the combination of thermodynamic analysis and in-situ characterization technique. The outcome of this work will provide an experimental basis for the construction of highly efficient Pt-based catalysts for selective EG oxidation to GA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6⋅6H2O) was purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. Alumina (γ-Al2O3) was obtained from Jiangsu Xianfeng Nanomaterial Technology Co., Ltd. EG (HOCH2CH2OH) was purchased from Fengchuan Chemistry Co., Ltd. All available with no additional purification. O2 (>99.99 %), H2 (>99.99 %), N2 (>99.99 %), 10 vol.% O2/Ar and 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixed gas were bought from Taiyuan Iron and Steel Group Co., Ltd., and deionized water was produced in the laboratory. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method. Typically, 0.2 g Al2O3 was impregnated with a 10 mL aqueous solution containing a certain amount of H2PtCl6⋅6H2O and then ultrasonically treated for 30 min. Afterward, the mixed solution was evaporated by stirring in a water bath at 80 °C and dried at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the sample was reduced in a 10 vol.% H2/N2 mixture gas at 300 °C for 4 h. The obtained catalyst is marked as xPt/Al2O3 (x represents the mass fraction of Pt, x = 0.80, 0.85, 0.90 and 1.00). 2.3 Characterization techniques 2.3.1 Conventional characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/max 2500 diffractometer, CuKα) was employed to determine the crystal phase of the catalysts. Surface area, average pore size and pore volume of Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) were measured using a Beishide 3H-2000PS2 analyzer. The content of Pt was determined by an inductively coupled plasma apparatus (ICP, ICP-OES 730). The microstructure and crystal plane spacing of the sample can be more intuitively displayed through transmission electron microscope (TEM, JSM-2100F, JEOL). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi analyzer. All binding energy (BE) values were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was tested on a Beijing Builder Electronic Technology company's PCA-1200 automated multipurpose adsorption equipment. Prior to testing, 100 mg unreduced catalyst was pretreated by Ar gas (30 mL/min) for 1 h at 200 °C, and then was heated to 700 °C in the 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixed gas (30 mL/min) at a rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3.2 In situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurement In situ DRIFTS test was carried out on a German Bruker spectrometer model INVENIO-S with MCT detector and Harrick diffuse reflectance accessory. Successive experiments were performed as follows: The sample was pretreated in Ar (30 mL/min) at 100 °C for 60 min. After being cooled down to room temperature, EG was purged into the in situ accessory by Ar bubble method until saturated adsorption. After Ar purge for 30 min, the sample was exposed to a O2 flow with the temperature rises from 30 to 70 °, during which the spectra were collected at an interval of 10 °. After warming up to 70 °C, the spectra were taken at 10 min intervals until 60 min. 2.4 Selective EG oxidation The catalytic reaction was performed using a 25 mL stainless-steel stirred autoclave (model SLM25; Beijing Century Senlang Experimental Apparatus Co., Ltd.). Typically, a mixture of catalyst and EG solution (10 mL, 0.3 mol/L) were placed into the reactor. The reactor was sealed and purged three times with O2, and then pressurized with O2 to 1.0 MPa. The reactor was heated to 70 °C and maintained for 8.0 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the products were collected by filtration. The liquid products were analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Agress 1100). The refractive index (Shodex RI-201H) and the chromatographic column (Shodex SUGAR SH1011) were equipped on the HPLC. 0.005 M H2SO4 solution was employed as the mobile phase. The gas products were detected using a Haixin GC-950 instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector. The catalytic performance can be described as the conversion of EG (CEG, %), the selectivity of GA (SGA, %), oxalic acid (OA) (SOA, %) and CO2 (SCO2, %) as well as turnover frequency (TOF). The specific calculation formulas are shown as below: (1) C EG = n c o n v e r t e d EG n i n i t i a l EG × 100 % (2) S GA = n p r o d u c e d GA n c o n v e r t e d EG × 100 % (3) S OA = n p r o d u c e d OA n c o n v e r t e d EG × 100 % (4) S CO 2 = n prod uced CO 2 2 n conv erted EG × 100 % (5) TOF = C EG X EG M Pt m cat w Pt D Pt x P t 0 T where CEG is the conversion of EG, XEG is the initial concentration of EG, MPt is the molar weight of Pt, mcat is the weight of catalyst, wPt is the mass fraction of Pt, DPt is the dispersion degree of Pt, x Pt 0 is the percentage of Pt0 and T is the reaction time. All TOF values are estimated at EG conversions <10 % to ensure that the average reaction rate is equal to the instantaneous reaction rate. 2.5 Thermodynamic analysis The reaction entropy change (Δ rS θ, J/T), reaction enthalpy change (Δ rH θ, kJ), Gibbs free energy change (Δ rG θ, kJ) and equilibrium constants (Kθ) for each side reaction at standard conditions (298.15 K, 101.325 kPa) were calculated by Eqs. (6)-(9). (6) Δ r H m θ = ∑ p r o d u c t n i Δ f H m , i θ − ∑ R e a c t a n t n i Δ f H m , i θ (7) Δ r S m θ = ∑ p r o d u c t n i S m , i θ − ∑ R e a c t a n t n i S m , i θ (8) Δ r G m θ = Δ r H m θ − 10 − 3 × T Δ r S m θ (9) K θ = e x p ( − Δ r G m θ R T ) 3 Results 3.1 Characterization results 3.1.1 Physical structure properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves of the pristine Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1 , and the detailed textural properties are listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(a), the Al2O3 support and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts exhibit type IV isotherm with a H3 hysteresis loop, suggesting the existence of mesoporous structure [38,39]. It is clearly observed from Fig. 1(b) that all the samples exhibit a bimodal pore size distribution concentrated at 8–9 nm and 10–20 nm, respectively. Compared with Al2O3 support, the Pt/Al2O3 catalysts show similar isotherms and pore size distribution, indicating that the introduction of Pt species has little effect on the texture properties due to the low metal loading. It can be seen from Table 1, with Pt loading rises from 0.80 wt% to 0.90 wt%, the BET surface area and total pore volume of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts show a slight decrease. However, when Pt loading reaches up to 1.00 wt%, the surface area obviously declines from 150 to 136 m2·g−1 accompanying with pore volume decreases from 0.76 to 0.56 cm3·g−1, which can be attributed to the blockage of the pores by larger Pt particles. Additionally, it can be known that the actual Pt concentration is slightly lower than that of the theoretical value in the Pt/Al2O3 catalysts as shown in Table 1. Fig. 2 (a) presents the XRD patterns of Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. In all cases, the diffraction peaks at 37.6°, 39.5°, 45.9° and 67.0° are ascribed to the (220), (311), (440) and (400) crystal planes of Al2O3 (JCPDS.10–0425), respectively [40–42]. Interestingly, compared with Al2O3 support, the diffraction peak intensity at about 39.8° significantly increases with the increase of Pt loading. In order to further clarify this observation, a peak fitting analysis of the XRD patterns is carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 2(b). No obvious diffraction peak of Pt at 39.8° can be distinguished when the Pt loading is lower than 0.85 wt%, beyond which the diffraction peak of Pt (111) appears at 39.8° and strengthens with further increase of Pt loading. According to the Scherrer equation, the Pt particle sizes of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts are calculated and depicted in Table 1. TEM images and the corresponding particle size distribution histograms of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . In all cases, Pt particles are uniformly distributed on the Al2O3 surface, and the average grain size increases from 1.4 to 2.6 nm with Pt loading rises from 0.80 wt% to 1.00 wt%, which is well consistent with the XRD results. The high resolution TEM image of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 3(a-d)) illustrates the lattice fringes with an interplanar distance of 0.22 nm, corresponding to the Pt (111) planes, which is strongly corroborated the XRD data [43]. In addition, Pt dispersion is calculated using the TEM method in the Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [44,45] and the calculated results are listed on the Table 1. As the Pt loading increased from 0.80 to 1.00 wt%, the average particle size of Pt grew from 1.4 to 2.6 nm, while the dispersion of Pt decreased from 69.9 % to 41.7 %. 3.1.2 Chemical structure properties The H2-TPR analysis results are shown in Fig. 4 (a). As for the pristine Al2O3, there is no reduction peak below 600 °C. While, the Pt/Al2O3 catalysts present three obvious reduction peaks. The first peak centered at around 210 °C is attributed to the reduction of the bulk of PtOx species weakly interacted with Al2O3, whereas the high-temperature peaks in the range between 300 and 500 °C is due to the reduction of PtOx species strongly interacted with Al2O3 [46,47]. Interestingly, it is noted that the three reduction peaks shift to the higher temperature with Pt loading increases from 0.80 wt% to 0.90 wt%, but sharply declines to lower temperatures with further elevating Pt loading to 1.00 wt%. Therefore, it can be known that 0.90Pt/Al2O3 shows much stronger metal-support interaction than the other catalysts, which is more conducive to anchoring Pt particles onto the Al2O3 surface. As depicted in Fig. 4(b), Pt 4d 5/2 XPS spectra can be fitted into three components with binding energy (BE) at about 312.8, 314.8 and 316.8 eV, corresponding to Pt0, Pt2+ and Pt4+, respectively [48]. It can be seen in Table 2 that there is an obvious shift in the BE of Pt0 with increasing Pt loading, which may be attributed to the interface electronic effect between Pt and Al2O3 support [28]. Moreover, 0.90Pt/Al2O3 shows a higher Pt0 concentration than that of the other catalysts. 3.2 Selective oxidation of EG Fig. 5 displays the catalytic test results of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts in the selective oxidation of EG. The EG conversion increases from 32.2 % to 74.2 % with Pt loading rises from 0.80 wt% to 0.90 wt%. However, the EG conversion decreases to 46.6 % when the Pt loading reaches up to 1.00 wt%. In particular, there is no obvious difference in the GA selectivity for all the catalysts. However, as the Pt loading increases, the selectivity of oxalic acid (OA) gradually decreases, accompanying the progressive increase of CO2 selectivity. The catalytic activity of the four catalysts obeys the orders of 0.90Pt/Al2O3 > 1.00Pt/Al2O3 > 0.85Pt/Al2O3 > 0.80Pt/Al2O3 according to the GA yield, and 0.90Pt/Al2O3 exhibits about two times GA yield (66.9 %) as high as that of the 0.80Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. 4 Discussions 4.1 Reaction mechanisms 4.1.1 Thermodynamic analysis In the EG selective oxidation reaction, possible reactions and corresponding reaction formula of R1-R6 are as follows: (R1) HOCH2CH2OH + 1/2 O2 → HOCH2CHO + H2O Kθ = 1098.9 (R2) HOCH2CHO + 1/2 O2 → HOCH2COOH Kθ = 10161.8 (R3) HOCH2COOH + O2 → HOOCCOOH + H2O Kθ = 10115.0 (R4) HOCH2COOH + O2 → HCOOH + CO2 + H2O Kθ = 10156.8 (R5) HOOCCOOH + 1/2 O2 → 2 CO2 + H2O Kθ = 10158.7 (R6) HCOOH + 1/2 O2 → CO2 + H2O Kθ = 10109.7 Table 3 summarizes the thermodynamic analysis results of reactions R1-R6 based on the corresponding thermodynamic parameters shown in Table S1. As shown in reactions R1 and R2, EG is firstly oxidated to glycolaldehyde and then further oxidated to GA. Notably, the K θ value of R2 is far higher than those of R3-R6, implying that the formation of GA is the most thermodynamically favorable, as reported in the previous studies [25,27]. In comparison, the index of K θ (R1) value is only 98.9 far lower than that of K θ (R2) value, indicating that GA production is largely constrained by the R1. Due to unfavorable deep oxidation and CC bond cleavage, GA can be further oxidized to form oxalic acid (OA), formic acid (FA) and CO2, as shown in R3-R6. According to the catalytic results, two by-products of OA and CO2 were exactly detected. By comparing the Kθ of the R3-R6, it is found that CO2 is more prone to be generated than OA, regardless of the pathway via GA or OA, which can be validated by in situ DRIFTS results (Fig. S1) [49]. With the rise of the activity of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, the selectivity of CO2 gradually increases accompanying with decreased OA selectivity. In addition, it should be illustrated that no FA is detected in the by-products although R5 is thermodynamically favorable. Table 4 . 4.1.2 Elementary reactions According to the results of thermodynamic analysis, the possible reaction paths for GA formation are shown in Fig. 6 (a). In order to verified the activation of reactant molecules and the formation of different intermediates as well as the final products in the selective oxidation of EG reaction, in-situ DRIFTS measurements were carried out on the 0.90Pt/Al2O3 catalyst and the results were collected in Figs. 6(b). 4.1.2.1 O2 activation It is well known that molecular O2 is not able to directly participate in the aerobic oxidation of alcohols [50–52]. Instead, there is a co-dissociation reaction of O2 and H2O on Pt to form adsorbed hydroxyl (OH*) and oxygen atom (O*), and the generated OH* is participate to the EG oxidation reaction [28]. The chemical dissociation and activation formula is as follows: (R7) O2* + H2O* →2OH* + O* 4.1.2.2 EG oxidation to glycolaldehyde During the in-situ DRIFTS measurements, with the increase of reaction temperature and the extension of reaction time, the weakened O–H stretching vibrations at 3235 cm−1 implies the hydroxyl groups of EG have been dehydrogenated. Meanwhile, the –C = O– band at 1634–1727 cm−1 and C–H bond stretching vibrations at 2842–3002 cm−1 are gradually increasing, indicative of the generation of the glycolaldehyde species, corresponding to R1 [53,54]. Additionally, the occurrence of EG oxidation to glycolaldehyde is also evidently consolidated by the progressive increase stretching vibrations at 3733 cm−1 corresponding to free hydroxyl groups or co-adsorbed water [55]. The reaction pathways of EG oxidation to glycolaldehyde are given in formulas (R8-R9): (R8) HOCH2CH2OH* → HOCH2CH2O* + H* (R9) HOCH2CH2O* → HOCH2CHO* + H* 4.1.2.3 Glycolaldehyde oxidation to GA The new double bands at 1395 and 1335 cm−1 assigned to the symmetrical stretching vibration of –OCO– (νs(OCO)) and symmetric deformation vibration of methylene and hydroxyl groups (δs(CH2) + δ(OH)) appear, which suggested the readily transformation of glycolaldehyde to GA (corresponding to R2) [55]. The signals at 1550 and 1460 cm−1 are assigned to the νas(COO) and νs(OCO) mode of carboxylate species was also observed [56]. The reaction pathway of glycolaldehyde oxidation to GA is given in formulas (R10-R11): (R10) HOCH2CHO* → HOCH2CO* + H* (R11) HOCH2CO* + OH* → HOCH2COOH In addition, the breaking of the CC bond leads to the production of CO2, and the reaction pathway is given in formulas (R12): (R12) HOCH2COOH* → HOCH2* + COOH* 4.2 Structure-properties relationship It can be observed that the TOF value is improved as the Pt loading increase from 0.80 wt% (250.0 h−1) to 0.90 wt% (1106.6 h−1), while it begins to fall once further elevating Pt loading up to 1.00 wt%. Furthermore, a strong linear relationship between TOF values and Pt0 concentration is observed in Fig. 7 , indicating Pt0 species serve as the active sites for GA formation via selective EG oxidation as reported in the literature [25,28]. 5 Conclusion The Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared and tested in the selective oxidative of EG under mild neutral conditions. The TOF value initially increases and then decreases as Pt loading become larger gradually, and the maximum (1106.6 h−1) is obtained on the 0.90Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, in situ DRIFTS measurement results verify the reaction pathways of EG oxidation as follows: C2H6O2 → HOCH2CHO → HOCH2COOH. It was found that a strong linear relationship between TOF values and Pt0 concentration, indicating Pt0 species serve as the active sites for GA formation. This work unraveled structure-performance relationship for the selective EG oxidation over Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, providing important guidance for the design of efficient noble catalysts especially for the oxidation reaction of polyols. coredata.dc:description: A series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were fabricated by finely adjusting the amount of platinum and investigated in the selective oxidative of ethylene glycol (EG) to glycolic acid (GA) under mild neutral conditions. The 0.90Pt/Al2O3 catalyst showed the maximum turnover frequency (TOF: 1106.6 h−1) with the EG conversion of 74.2 % and GA selectivity of 90.2 %. A strong linear relationship between TOF values and Pt0concentration was revealed, confirming that Pt0 species serves as the active sites for GA formation. In addition, in situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) results verify the reaction pathways of EG oxidation as follows: C2H6O2 → HOCH2CHO → HOCH2COOH. This work unraveled structure-performance relationship for the selective EG oxidation over Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, providing important guidance for the design of efficient noble catalysts especially for the oxidation reaction of polyols.
